title: "The Connection between Irish and Arthurian Legends"
first_phrase: In the previous text, Julius Evola traces the origins of the Grail legend back to ancient Celtic traditions and symbols. He discusses various rebellions against ruling dynasties in Ireland, as recorded in Los Anales de los Cuatro Maestros. The rebellion led by the "plebeian race" against the noble class resulted in a devastating curse, which could only be lifted by the return of the hero. The saga of Alexander the Great's drought-ridden campaign, which occurred during the time of Gog and Magog, is a similar event. In this concluding section, the author explores the connection between these ancient Celtic traditions and the legend of King Arthur.
content: Ahora bien, en la saga oriental de Alejandro, se habla de la devastación y la sequía «de todos los ríos y arroyos, hasta el punto de no dejar un solo sorbo de agua», y eso lo sitúa en el tiempo de la venida de las gentes de Gog y Magog. Son las mismas circunstancias en que acaba el reino del Grial, convertido en la Gaste Terre, la tierra devastada a causa del denominado «golpe doloroso», y que no cesará hasta el regreso del héroe vengador y restaurador. Ya este conjunto de antiguas tradiciones y de arcaicos símbolos célticos precristianos presenta los temas principales que, por decirlo así, se reencamarán en las leyendas del Grial. El otro eslabón de conexión es la saga del rey Arturo. IX.
last_phrase: In conclusion, the legends of the Grail and King Arthur have common themes and ancient symbols that continue to fascinate and inspire us. The devastating environmental conditions described in these sagas remind us of the fragility of our planet and the need for responsible stewardship. The enduring appeal of King Arthur as a symbol of heroic leadership speaks to the timeless human desire for a champion who can restore order and justice to our troubled world.
